the Assembly next Thursday on the
subject of "The British Occupation
of Palestine." During the past
summer, Dr. Birckhead and Rabbi
Lazaron, of the Baltimore Hebrew
Congregation, took an extensive
sightseeing tour throughout the
Near East for the purpose of studying conditions there. Since returning to this country he has delivered several lectures on his trip,
which have attracted widespread
interest.
Ever since Dr. Birckhead has
been connected with Emmanuel
Church, he has been recognized as
one of Baltimore's few real live
wires of the clergy, and whenever
he speaks it is always to an overpacked audience. He has taken
several trips to Europe and the
Near East, and is widely known as
a lecturer on travel. His subject
for next Thursday is one of great
religious consequence for the question of the future of Palestine is
in the minds of men of all sects.
At present the British are ruling it
as a protectorate, but it is very
probable that Palestine will become a sovereign nation in the near4
future.
Dr. Birckhead, as a speaker,
should draw the largest crowd that
has ever attended a Hopkins Assembly, and Dean Latane hopes
that the student body will turn out
in force. Eminent speakers and
good atendance will determine the
future of the Hopkins Assemblies
and as the former will be supplied
Thursday it is hoped that the latter will also be present.

The first concert of the present
season was given by the Musical
Clubs to the blind soldiers at Evergreen last Tuesday, and was followed by a performance on Saturday at McDonogh School. Although there still remain some
rough edges to be smoothed over,
it is felt that on both occasions the
clubs reflected credit upon themselves by their rendition of popular
and University selections. Both
concerts were followed by dances.
Many Hopkins men made the trip
to McDonogh, and it will be agreed
by all who attended that it was well
worth the trouble.
An admission of fifty cents was
charged.

gram of presenting the biography
of each player on our championship
team, we now present the regular
linesmen (The Flying Gumps).
These men proved themselves to
be towers of strength when it
came to stopping the rushes of our
opponents and never failed to open
up holes for the backs to plow
through.
Although often up
against heavier and more experienced players, they always showed
their superiority.
In a previous issue the "lives" of
Bill Totterdale and Magill, of the
line, were published. We will now
give you the past, present and future history of Knecht, I,andy,
Middleton, Westerman and Rich.
Andrew Henry Knecht—"Andy
Gump"—our heaviest linesman,
weighs 195 pounds and is 23 years
old. This is his last year of a fouryear engineering course. Andy,
who lives in Baltimore, went
through Poly and carried away
scholastic and baseball honors. He
did not, however, play any football. Not until his third year here
did he go out for football, but that
year he made the team, won his
"H," and became one of the mainstays of the line. This year he
played in every game and developed into an excellent tackle. Next
spring we will hear from Andy as
captain and star pitcher of the
baseball team.
Thomas Mathew Landy is 21
years old and weighs 165 pounds.
This is Tom's third year in the
University and also his third year
as guard on the varsity. He is a
Baltimore boy and came here from
Loyola High, where he played
guard for four years. Tom not
only made the team in his first
year, but was also All-Maryland
choice both that year and the following one. This year he played
all of the time, with the exception
of about a half minute in the Washington and Lee game. He is a
basket-ball player and also a lacrosse candidate. Next year will
see his return—to again hold down
his old job.
Samuel Atherton Middleton, our
speedy little left end, is 20 years
old and weighs 150 pounds. He
comes from the wilds of the Eastern Shore, Maryland, his home
town being Centerville. Marston's
was the prep school that "Happy"
chose and there he played football,
basket-ball and baseball. He was
on the football squad at Hopkins
his first year, and has been on the
varsity for the last two years. He
will be back with us again next
year. Next spring "Happy" will
be out with the baseball team and
during the winter months he will
be down at the B. A. C. with the
swimmers.
Luther Westerman — Chester
Gump—is our other big tackle. He
is 22 years old and weighs 193
pounds. "Westy" went to Poly
and played on the football team
there. He was in the Navy during
the war and was consequently out

Held by a smoother-running
Freshman machine to a scoreless
tie through four periods of a
fiercely fought football game, baffled in their attempt to obtain the
verdant banner of the first-year
men-in the first half of the annual
rush, the Sophomores succeeded
in making the afternoon a memorable one from the standpoint of
the class of 1924 by tearing the
coveted banner from its moorings
soon after the beginning of the
second half of the rush. Although
the field was still soggy from the
inclement weather of the early
part of the week, thus making life
miserable for the combatants, the
day was otherwise an ideal one,
and many interested spectators
were on hand, cheering enthusiastically for their favorites—be it
class or individual. Now and then
as friends were seen to disappear
in depths of the howling mob during the rush a look of fear was
seen to flit across the faces of
some of the female spectators.
Said friends, however, always succeeded in arising and taking their
part in the melee and the interested one forgot their fears and urged
them on with shouts of encouragement.
Although outplayed by the
Freshmen in the football game,
the Sophomore line proved invincible as soon as their goal line was
threatened and the first-year men
were unable to put the ball across
for a score. Three times did the
Freshmen threaten to carry the
ball over. In the second quarter
they advanced by forward passes
and line-plunging to within three
yards of a touchdown, when the
Sophomore line, desperate, tackled so hard that Merlees fumbled
and the ball was recovered by a
second-year man and punted out
of danger. In the third quarter the
Freshies again carried the ball to
the Sophomores' 15-yard line,
only to be held for downs. In the
last quarter Balsam got away on a
50-yard end run and it seemed certain that the Sophomore goal line
would be crossed. But Referee
Totterdale had detected a firstyear man in the act of holding and
the ball was called back and a 15yard penalty allotted.
Time and again the Frosh carried the ball down the field, only
to lose it on downs by a fumble,
or by an intercepted forward
pass. Dorsey was instrumental
in keeping the Soph goal line inviolable by intercepting two
passes at critical moments.
The second-year men showed
but little on the offensive and displayed utter lack of teamwork.
The runner seldom followed his
interference and was often tripped
or blocked by his own men. Only
four first downs were made by the
Sophs to eleven by the Freshmen.
Merlees and Balsam, by their
runs, and Captain Summers and
Young, by their stellar defensive
work, showed up best for the
Freshmen. Homer and Dunning,
on the Sophomore wings, threw

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, But Shoulder the Responsibility.
All letters intended for publication
must be concise, written in ink on
regular letter size paper, on one side
only.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be
printed if request is made that they be
omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to
be taken as an indorsement of its views
by the "News-Letter," which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir: I should like to take
this opportunity to suggest to the
A. A. Board, and for the approval
of the student body, that that assistant manager designated by the
Coach in each major sport be
awarded an "H. A. A." for his efforts during the season. The assistant managers are always given
the dirty jobs that arise in the
course of managing and they usually spend as much time in actual
work as do the regular managers!
Why, then, should the assistants be
neglected when rewards and honors are passed out? Certainly the
awarding of the "Ii. A. A." to
worthy men would not lower its
value and it would serve as an inspiration to would-be managers
just starting on their career. The
writer of this letter, it might be explained, is not a candidate for any
managership.
This new idea
should certainly be given close consideration by the entire student
body.

To the Editor of the News-Letter,
Dear Sir:
In some strange manner the
heavy spring cardboard covers for
the magazines in the readingroom of the Barn have been disappearing with monotonous regularity. We appreciate the fact
that they make good notebocl
covers, but having to buy them we
also know that they are expensive, and furthermore, are needed
to keep the magazines in good
condition. If you find the copy of
Life only half there or the Illustrated London News with the best
part gone, don't come to us asking where is the rest of the issue,
but look around and jump on the
guilty member yourself.
V. J.'WYCKOFF,
Asst. Sec'y Y. M. C. A., J. H. U.

JOSIAH MORSE TO LECTURE THIS
AFTERNOON

The Social Science Club has announced a lecture by Professor Josiah Morse, of the University of
South Carolina, on "The Philosophy of Race Relationship in the
South." The lecture will be given
in the lecture room of the C. E.
Building on Tuesday, December
13, at 4:15 P. M. The subject is
a timely one, because of the renewed interest in it aroused by
President Harding's recent address
in Birmingham, Ala. The club
has already held a meeting at which
a paper on this topic was read, and
an informal discussion of the present racial situation and means of
bettering it ensued. Professor
Morse's speech ought to prove of
interest to all who are alive to one
of our most serious national problems.

INTERFRATERNITY INITIATES TO
ENTERTAIN UPPERCLASSMEN

The first inter-fraternity smoker
of the year will be in charge of the
newly initiated men. The smoker
Will be held in the Barn on December 19. This and other details were
decided at a meeting of the committee of the new men in charge
held yesterday.
The smoker will be enlivened by
stunts put on by each fraternity
-roup of new men. The committee consists of G. Klinefelter, Phi
Gamma Delta, chairman; A. L.
Dryden, Pi Kappa Chi; P. 0.'Connor, Phi Kappa Psi; R. T. Regester, Kappa Alpha; L. Westerman,
Kappa Sigma; J. H. Huffard, Alpha Delta Phi; Gross, Delta Phi;
Betts Slingluff, Beta Theta Pi,
and D. Klein, Omicron Kappa Omicron.

that will turn out a championship
team for Hopkins next year.
The head coach for next year

the Assembly next Thursday on the
subject of "The British Occupation
of Palestine." During the past
summer, Dr. Birckhead and Rabbi
Lazaron, of the Baltimore Hebrew
Congregation, took an extensive
sightseeing tour throughout the
Near East for the purpose of studying conditions there. Since returning to this country he has delivered several lectures on his trip,
which have attracted widespread
interest.
Ever since Dr. Birckhead has
been connected with Emmanuel
Church, he has been recognized as
one of Baltimore's few real live
wires of the clergy, and whenever
he speaks it is always to an overpacked audience. He has taken
several trips to Europe and the
Near East, and is widely known as
a lecturer on travel. His subject
for next Thursday is one of great
religious consequence for the question of the future of Palestine is
in the minds of men of all sects.
At present the British are ruling it
as a protectorate, but it is very
probable that Palestine will become a sovereign nation in the near4
future.
Dr. Birckhead, as a speaker,
should draw the largest crowd that
has ever attended a Hopkins Assembly, and Dean Latane hopes
that the student body will turn out
in force. Eminent speakers and
good atendance will determine the
future of the Hopkins Assemblies
and as the former will be supplied
Thursday it is hoped that the latter will also be present.

The first concert of the present
season was given by the Musical
Clubs to the blind soldiers at Evergreen last Tuesday, and was followed by a performance on Saturday at McDonogh School. Although there still remain some
rough edges to be smoothed over,
it is felt that on both occasions the
clubs reflected credit upon themselves by their rendition of popular
and University selections. Both
concerts were followed by dances.
Many Hopkins men made the trip
to McDonogh, and it will be agreed
by all who attended that it was well
worth the trouble.
An admission of fifty cents was
charged.

gram of presenting the biography
of each player on our championship
team, we now present the regular
linesmen (The Flying Gumps).
These men proved themselves to
be towers of strength when it
came to stopping the rushes of our
opponents and never failed to open
up holes for the backs to plow
through.
Although often up
against heavier and more experienced players, they always showed
their superiority.
In a previous issue the "lives" of
Bill Totterdale and Magill, of the
line, were published. We will now
give you the past, present and future history of Knecht, I,andy,
Middleton, Westerman and Rich.
Andrew Henry Knecht—"Andy
Gump"—our heaviest linesman,
weighs 195 pounds and is 23 years
old. This is his last year of a fouryear engineering course. Andy,
who lives in Baltimore, went
through Poly and carried away
scholastic and baseball honors. He
did not, however, play any football. Not until his third year here
did he go out for football, but that
year he made the team, won his
"H," and became one of the mainstays of the line. This year he
played in every game and developed into an excellent tackle. Next
spring we will hear from Andy as
captain and star pitcher of the
baseball team.
Thomas Mathew Landy is 21
years old and weighs 165 pounds.
This is Tom's third year in the
University and also his third year
as guard on the varsity. He is a
Baltimore boy and came here from
Loyola High, where he played
guard for four years. Tom not
only made the team in his first
year, but was also All-Maryland
choice both that year and the following one. This year he played
all of the time, with the exception
of about a half minute in the Washington and Lee game. He is a
basket-ball player and also a lacrosse candidate. Next year will
see his return—to again hold down
his old job.
Samuel Atherton Middleton, our
speedy little left end, is 20 years
old and weighs 150 pounds. He
comes from the wilds of the Eastern Shore, Maryland, his home
town being Centerville. Marston's
was the prep school that "Happy"
chose and there he played football,
basket-ball and baseball. He was
on the football squad at Hopkins
his first year, and has been on the
varsity for the last two years. He
will be back with us again next
year. Next spring "Happy" will
be out with the baseball team and
during the winter months he will
be down at the B. A. C. with the
swimmers.
Luther Westerman — Chester
Gump—is our other big tackle. He
is 22 years old and weighs 193
pounds. "Westy" went to Poly
and played on the football team
there. He was in the Navy during
the war and was consequently out

rush, the Sophomores succeeded
in making the afternoon a memorable one from the standpoint of
the class of 1924 by tearing the
coveted banner from its moorings
soon after the beginning of the
second half of the rush. Although
the field was still soggy from the
inclement weather of the early
part of the week, thus making life
miserable for the combatants, the
day was otherwise an ideal one,
and many interested spectators
were on hand, cheering enthusiastically for their favorites—be it
class or individual. Now and then
as friends were seen to disappear
in depths of the howling mob during the rush a look of fear was
seen to flit across the faces of
some of the female spectators.
Said friends, however, always succeeded in arising and taking their
part in the melee and the interested one forgot their fears and urged
them on with shouts of encouragement.
Although outplayed by the
Freshmen in the football game,
the Sophomore line proved invincible as soon as their goal line was
threatened and the first-year men
were unable to put the ball across
for a score. Three times did the
Freshmen threaten to carry the
ball over. In the second quarter
they advanced by forward passes
and line-plunging to within three
yards of a touchdown, when the
Sophomore line, desperate, tackled so hard that Merlees fumbled
and the ball was recovered by a
second-year man and punted out
of danger. In the third quarter the
Freshies again carried the ball to
the Sophomores' 15-yard line,
only to be held for downs. In the
last quarter Balsam got away on a
50-yard end run and it seemed certain that the Sophomore goal line
would be crossed. But Referee
Totterdale had detected a firstyear man in the act of holding and
the ball was called back and a 15yard penalty allotted.
Time and again the Frosh carried the ball down the field, only
to lose it on downs by a fumble,
or by an intercepted forward
pass. Dorsey was instrumental
in keeping the Soph goal line inviolable by intercepting two
passes at critical moments.
The second-year men showed
but little on the offensive and displayed utter lack of teamwork.
The runner seldom followed his
interference and was often tripped
or blocked by his own men. Only
four first downs were made by the
Sophs to eleven by the Freshmen.
Merlees and Balsam, by their
runs, and Captain Summers and
Young, by their stellar defensive
work, showed up best for the
Freshmen. Homer and Dunning,
on the Sophomore wings, threw

A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, But Shoulder the Responsibility.
All letters intended for publication
must be concise, written in ink on
regular letter size paper, on one side
only.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be
printed if request is made that they be
omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to
be taken as an indorsement of its views
by the "News-Letter," which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir: I should like to take
this opportunity to suggest to the
A. A. Board, and for the approval
of the student body, that that assistant manager designated by the
Coach in each major sport be
awarded an "H. A. A." for his efforts during the season. The assistant managers are always given
the dirty jobs that arise in the
course of managing and they usually spend as much time in actual
work as do the regular managers!
Why, then, should the assistants be
neglected when rewards and honors are passed out? Certainly the
awarding of the "Ii. A. A." to
worthy men would not lower its
value and it would serve as an inspiration to would-be managers
just starting on their career. The
writer of this letter, it might be explained, is not a candidate for any
managership.
This new idea
should certainly be given close consideration by the entire student
body.

To the Editor of the News-Letter,
Dear Sir:
In some strange manner the
heavy spring cardboard covers for
the magazines in the readingroom of the Barn have been disappearing with monotonous regularity. We appreciate the fact
that they make good notebocl
covers, but having to buy them we
also know that they are expensive, and furthermore, are needed
to keep the magazines in good
condition. If you find the copy of
Life only half there or the Illustrated London News with the best
part gone, don't come to us asking where is the rest of the issue,
but look around and jump on the
guilty member yourself.
V. J.'WYCKOFF,
Asst. Sec'y Y. M. C. A., J. H. U.

JOSIAH MORSE TO LECTURE THIS
AFTERNOON

The Social Science Club has announced a lecture by Professor Josiah Morse, of the University of
South Carolina, on "The Philosophy of Race Relationship in the
South." The lecture will be given
in the lecture room of the C. E.
Building on Tuesday, December
13, at 4:15 P. M. The subject is
a timely one, because of the renewed interest in it aroused by
President Harding's recent address
in Birmingham, Ala. The club
has already held a meeting at which
a paper on this topic was read, and
an informal discussion of the present racial situation and means of
bettering it ensued. Professor
Morse's speech ought to prove of
interest to all who are alive to one
of our most serious national problems.

INTERFRATERNITY INITIATES TO
ENTERTAIN UPPERCLASSMEN

The first inter-fraternity smoker
of the year will be in charge of the
newly initiated men. The smoker
Will be held in the Barn on December 19. This and other details were
decided at a meeting of the committee of the new men in charge
held yesterday.
The smoker will be enlivened by
stunts put on by each fraternity
-roup of new men. The committee consists of G. Klinefelter, Phi
Gamma Delta, chairman; A. L.
Dryden, Pi Kappa Chi; P. 0.'Connor, Phi Kappa Psi; R. T. Regester, Kappa Alpha; L. Westerman,
Kappa Sigma; J. H. Huffard, Alpha Delta Phi; Gross, Delta Phi;
Betts Slingluff, Beta Theta Pi,
and D. Klein, Omicron Kappa Omicron.
